text: So very quickly, I was at Nomura from 91 to 94. I got a hold of this Cox and Rubenstein book, this red book on binomial trees and options market. I was enthralled. And one of my closest friends, Ross Stevens, was a PhD student at the University of Chicago at the time, has made a gigantic gift to the PhD program. It's now named the Stevens doctoral program at the University of Chicago. And he sold me on becoming or trying to get into the MBA program, which thankfully I did at the UFC. I joined there in 94. I studied econometrics and modeling and so forth for options. And I joined the Lehman Brothers equity derivatives desk in 1996. It's a pretty low period for vol in 96. We're talking 11 and 12 VIX. We started doing trades like vol swaps. I remember doing some of those at 12, which was extraordinary low, but I learned a little bit about vol. And through 96, through 97, Asian contagion hit. In 97, the VIX momentarily got to 40 as the IMF had to intervene. I think it was October of 97. Pretty extraordinary. Things quieted down, but I was covering LTCM. I was enthralled by this group of all-stars coming out of Solomon, Bond arbitrage. What a team. Meriwether, Larry Hillebrand. You had Victor Higani in Europe. You had backup from the Fed. David Mullins was the ex-vice chair of the Fed. And then of course you had Scholes and Merton. It's really black Scholes, Merton. Some people even think that Merton deserves more credit in some ways for kind of finalizing some of these proofs. But these are two extraordinary, extraordinary academics that are at LTCM. LTCM's own interpretation of itself, they call themselves a financial technology company. They were very, very focused on the math behind these trades, whether it was convergence trades, but they were an extremely, extremely bright and mathy group. Most of them were in some ways professors from MIT. And again, it was incredible to have an opportunity to cover them. We did some very interesting options trades, not just incredibly sizable, but there were some interesting correlation trades we did on spread assets. And so they really thought a lot about optionality. That was really, to me in the DNA of the firm, was to think about risk from a... These guys weren't stock pickers. They never put themselves out. They weren't studying the newspaper and looking for the next big product. They were literally focused on trying to find inefficiencies in the market where they could step in and be a liquidity provider and get compensated for bearing gap risk. And did it incredibly successfully in 94, 95, 96, and 97. The compound return for those four years has got to be 35 to 40%. And that's after fees. And to me, one of the lessons I just sort of look at myself as this is the success and the resumes of these folks to me made the strategies just self-evident in terms of how good these guys were. I saw it in how the process of getting credit approval was for them internally. I could bully my credit officer and say it's LTCM. And there was some part of, look, do you want to do the business or not? Because Merrill or Goldman or Morgan Stanley will do it at basically 0% collateral. And then there was a second part, which is these guys are successful. So you don't have to worry about the credit risk. These guys aren't going to lose money. So there was a combination of, look, we want to be involved, but also, you know how good these guys are. So to me, there's a lot of lessons there.
